[File: aptos-core/storage/backup/backup-cli/src/utils/backup_service_client.rs] [Function: get_account_range_proof()] [Merkle Proof Tampering] Can a malicious backup service return invalid or incomplete Merkle proofs that pass validation but prove incorrect state, allowing validators to restore to a forked chain state? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/storage/backup/backup-cli/src/utils/backup_service_client.rs] [Function: get_state_root_proof()] [State Root Forgery] Can an attacker manipulate the returned state root proof in line 127-133 to make validators accept an invalid state root, causing state divergence and potential chain splits? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/storage/backup/backup-cli/src/utils/backup_service_client.rs] [Function: get_transaction_range_proof()] [Transaction Proof Attack] Can a compromised backup service provide transaction range proofs that verify correctly but omit or reorder transactions, allowing validators to restore incomplete or reordered transaction history? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/storage/backup/backup-cli/src/utils/backup_service_client.rs] [Function: get_state_snapshot_chunk()] [Chunk Consistency] Can an attacker provide inconsistent state snapshot chunks across multiple requests (e.g., chunks from different versions) that individually verify but create an inconsistent overall state when combined? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/storage/backup/backup-cli/src/utils/backup_service_client.rs] [Function: get_epoch_ending_ledger_infos()] [Epoch Info Manipulation] Can a malicious backup service return fabricated epoch-ending ledger infos with valid signatures but incorrect validator sets, causing restored validators to reject legitimate blocks from the correct validator set? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/storage/backup/backup-cli/src/utils/backup_service_client.rs] [Function: get_state_snapshot_chunk()] [Version Mismatch] In line 116, can an attacker request chunks for a version number that doesn't exist or is far in the future, causing the backup service to return garbage data or crash? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/storage/backup/backup-cli/src/utils/backup_service_client.rs] [Function: get_account_range_proof()] [Invalid Version] In line 101, can specifying version 0 or u64::MAX cause undefined behavior in the backup service's proof generation, potentially returning proofs for non-existent state? [File: aptos-core/storage/backup/backup-cli/src/utils/backup_service_client.rs] [Function: get_epoch_ending_ledger_infos()] [Epoch Boundary Attack] In line 136-145, can an attacker specify start_epoch=0 and end_epoch=u64::MAX to force the backup service to scan and return the entire epoch history, causing extreme CPU/memory usage? [File: aptos-core/storage/backup/backup-cli/src/utils/backup_service_client.rs] [Function: get_transactions()] [Historical Data Attack] In line 148-157, can requesting transactions from version 0 with num_transactions=usize::MAX cause the backup service to attempt streaming the entire blockchain history, exhausting resources? (High)

[File: aptos-core/storage/backup/backup-cli/src/utils/backup_service_client.rs] [Function: get_state_root_proof()] [Future Version] Can requesting a state root proof for a version that doesn't exist yet cause the backup service to block indefinitely or return uninitialized data? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/storage/backup/backup-cli/src/utils/backup_service_client.rs] [Function: get()] [Authorization Bypass] Can an attacker exploit the lack of request signing or API keys to impersonate legitimate backup clients and retrieve sensitive validator data or manipulate backup operations? [File: aptos-core/storage/backup/backup-cli/src/utils/backup_service_client.rs] [Function: get()] [Rate Limiting] Is there any rate limiting on backup requests, or can an attacker flood the backup service with thousands of concurrent requests to degrade validator performance during consensus?
